xxl.cursors
Class Repeater

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--xxl.cursors.Repeater
public class Repeater
extends Object
implements Cursor

A Repeater repeats a given object n times.

The times this object is repeated can be specified by the caller.
Even it is possible to repeat a given object infinitely.

Example usage (1): 

 	Repeater repeater = new Repeater(new Integer(1));
 		for(int i=0; i<10; i++)
 			System.out.print(repeater.next() +"; ");
 		System.out.flush(); System.out.println();
 		repeater.close();
This instance of a Repeater would return the Integer-object with value 1 infinitely.
Therefore the for-loop is used to return only the first ten elements.
As result the given Integer-object is returned ten times and printed to the output stream.

Example usage (2): 

 	repeater = new Repeater(new Integer(1), 10);
 		while(repeater.hasNext())
 			System.out.print(repeater.next() +"; ");
 		System.out.flush(); System.out.println();
 		repeater.close();
This example shows a Repeater with a given Integer-object '1', which is returned for ten times, because in this case the user specified the parameter times in the constructor.
The output is equal to that of example(1).

See Also:

Constructor Detail

Creates a new Repeater. This Repeater repeats the input-object infinitely.
Parameters:

                int times)
Creates a new Repeater.
Parameters:
object - the Object to be repeated.
times - the number of times the object should be repeated.
Method Detail

close

public void close()
Closes the Repeater. Signals the cursor to cleanup resources, close files, etc.
After a call to close calls to methods like next or peek are not guarantied to yield proper results.
Multiple calls to close() do not have any effect, i.e. if close() was called the Repeater remains in the state "closed".
Specified by:
close in interface Cursor

hasNext

public boolean hasNext()
Returns true if the iteration has more elements.
(In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)
If the caller did not specified the times the object should be repeated hasNext will return true every time.
Specified by:
hasNext in interface Cursor
Returns:
true if the Repeater has more elements.

next

public Object next()
            throws NoSuchElementException
Returns the next element in the iteration, that means the Object is given back again.
If the caller specified the times this Object should be returned, the field left is decremented after a call to next.
Specified by:
next in interface Cursor
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - iteration has no more elements.

peek

public Object peek()
            throws NoSuchElementException,
                   UnsupportedOperationException
Shows the next element in the iteration, that means the Object is given back again, but the field left is not decremented.
Specified by:
peek in interface Cursor
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - iteration has no more elements.
UnsupportedOperationException - if the peek operation is not supported by this Repeater. (not possible)

remove

public void remove()
            throws UnsupportedOperationException
This method is not supported by a Repeater.
If this method is called an UnsupportedOperationException is thrown.
Specified by:
remove in interface Cursor
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the remove operation is not supported by this Repeater.

reset

public void reset()
           throws UnsupportedOperationException
This method resets the Repeater to its initial state.
If the Object is only repeated finitely this method sets the value of the field left to the value of the field times, so the caller is able to receive the given Object for the specified times again.
Specified by:
reset in interface Cursor
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the reset method is not supported by the Repeater. (not possible)

supportsPeek

public boolean supportsPeek()
A Repeater always supports the peek method, so true will be returned by a call to this method.
Specified by:
supportsPeek in interface Cursor
Returns:
true if the peek operation is supported by this Repeater.

update

public void update(Object object)
            throws UnsupportedOperationException
This method is not supported by Repeaters.
If this method is called an UnsupportedOperationException is thrown.
Specified by:
update in interface Cursor
Parameters:
object - the object that replaces the object returned by the last call to next or peek.
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the update operation is not supported by this Repeater.

main

public static void main(String[] args)
The main method contains some examples to demonstrate the usage and the functionality of this class.
Parameters:
args - array of String arguments. It can be used to submit parameters when the main method is called.
